content.description:
This is described as "more of a nightmare" in the guidebook.  On the contrary, its actually quite cool.

Wet Dreams ascends the steep upper right side of the wall directly above Flower of High Rank via an obvious wide right-arching crack.

The climbing consists of bomber hand jams and a tough move into a downward sloping slot that can fit your entire body.  The final exit move out of the crack will keep your attention for the entirety of the short pitch.
content.location:
You can get to Wet Dreams from Flower of High Rank or Etude. Belay above Flower's roof. Due to the route's traversing nature, it is impossible to TR.

It is also possible to do this pitch directly from the Etude anchors.

climbs.name: Vicious Rumors
climbs.fa: Mike Lechlinski, Randy Leavitt, and Mari Gingery, 1982

content.description:
This is the left-facing corner with a thin crack located just right of Spooky Spike Direct.

A demanding lead.

Layback up a large hanging flake to a small roof.  The flake is solid enough to climb on but, Its probably a bad idea to stuff cams behind it and fall on it.  Setting an anchor at the top of Wet Dreams and lowering in is the safest and most convenient way to access this short, steep climb.
content.location: Near the top of Cat's Cave Inn (at the location of a fixed pin) climb up the steep side of the dihedral, up the left side of a large hanging flake to a small roof at the top of the right side of the North East Buttress.  This route shares the same top-out moves as Wet Dreams.

climbs.name: Spooky Spike Direct
climbs.fa: Randy Leavitt and Brett Mauer, June 1981

content.description: Intersesting stemming between the shallow corners to the right of Rock Hudson. For a safe lead, this one requires a fixed pin or two. As it is (without the pins) it's definately an R rated lead, but is a fun toprope.

climbs.name: Spooky Spike
climbs.fa: Charlie Raymond, W. Burke, and Paul Raymond, December, 1968

content.description: Start up Flake Out, but stop well before the offwidth.  Pitch 2 is the crux - a thin crack in a dihedral.  It finishes on top of the rock - walk off to the right.  This climb is in the sun only in the morning.

climbs.name: Rock Hudson
climbs.fa: FA:  Dave Evans, Margy Floyd (A3) 1985  FFA :  TR Bob Gaines 1987  FL:  Andy Puhvel, 1989

content.description:
This thin crack/seam starts inbetween the routes

Flakes of Wrath

and Vicious Rumors (5.11c R). This tips crack ends at the traversing route Flake Out, and finish up the rock on a variety of routes.

climbs.name: Race Bannon
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Mike Moretti, July 2000

content.description: This is the short face with a thin crack on the slab directly beneath Johnny Quest.

climbs.name: My Brothers
climbs.fa: Scott Cosgrove and Bob Gaines, October 1993.

content.description: Climb the start of Spooky Spike Direct, then step right and climb a challenging arete.

Pitch 1 (crux) is a classic steep finger crack.  You can either rappel 90' from the top of this pitch or continue to the top with the second pitch of Flake Out (5.6) or Flakes of Wrath (5.9R).  This climb is in the shade after mid-morning for most of the year.
Undercling across a wild arch in a dihedral.  A wild, steep and exposed line.
content.location: Start up Flower of High Rank, halfway to the tree traverse left across the dihedral under an obvious arch feature until you join Etude.  Continue up Etude to the anchors.

climbs.name: Hidden Crack
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Dayle Mazzarella, August 1996

content.description: Start with Flake Out and climb past the first vertical corner and belay as for Spooky Spike. Traverse up and left for 30 feet to just before Flake Out's wide crack, then lieback a thin flake system over a bulge, joining Spooky Spike to finish.

climbs.name: Hey Dude
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Clark Jacobs, and Lisa Fry, July 1991

content.description: Same start as Etude, but instead of moving right to the middle thin crack, continue up the leftmost crack up to a thin fingertip lieback crux protected by two bolts, finishing at the 2-bolt Etude belay stance. (35-meter rappel)

climbs.name: Flower of High Rank
climbs.fa: Rob Muir and Mike Graham, October '72

content.description:
The classic moderate crack at Suicide. You'll never tire of repeating this gem.

The climb is located where the Northeast Face becomes the North face and is easily identified by the tree (the flower?) growing right in the middle of the crack about 70 feet up.  The tree is historically littered with slings to help identify it.  The climb is just to the left of a huge (undesirable looking) right facing corner.. and you actually start up this corner to get to the main crack.

I prefer to do this climb in one long pitch, usually scrambling up to the base of the main crack for the first belay (some might want to rope this bit - and you'll need to build an anchor).  With a 200' rope you could belay from the ground, but there's enough rope drag already so why add more.  You can do the climb in two pitches and belay at the tree, but it is kind of a pain in the butt.

Once climbing you'll enjoy some quality jamming/stemming in the first section heading to the tree.  Sustained moves from fingers to off-fingers to thin-hands will get you to the tree and a nice comfy rest.  Want a 10a variety... don't use the left wall - my friend accidently did this and bitched his way up....

From the tree there are two cracks, one heading straight up and the other trending out a wild looking face to the right.  The right crack has your name on it.  Spectacular, exposed climbing up this arching crack leads to the route's final crux at the roof.  The roof goes at 5.9, but take your time to figure it out... many a flailing here.

Some 5.7 jamming finishes the journey.

What a climb!
content.protection:
Standard rack including nuts, and 2x each cam from small ones to a #3

(I did this from five year old memory, so feel free to add more specific gear requirements)

climbs.name: Flakes of Wrath
climbs.fa: John Bachar, Gib Lewis, Jim Wilson, John Long, Eric Erickson, and Tobin Sorenson, 1978

content.description: Pitch 1 is the crux, with strenuous lieback and hand jams in good rock.  The 5.9 second pitch is runout.  It finishes on top of the rock - walk off to the right.  This route is in the shade after mid-morning

climbs.name: Flakes of Rad
climbs.fa: Dave Wonderly, David Evans, Robin Erler

content.description: Climb the lieback of Flakes of Wrath to the roof where FOW goes left and go right to a ledge. Climb the face above to join Flake Out. Several options above to finish.
content.protection: Same as for Flakes of Wrath

climbs.name: Flake Out
climbs.fa: Pat Callis, Charlie and Paul Raymond, September, 1967

content.description: This is a well-protected two pitch crack climb, that traverses left for a long ways as it moves up.  The crux is a short offwidth near the end of pitch 1.  It finishes on top of the rock - walk off to the right.  This climb is in the shade most of the day.

climbs.name: Etude direct start
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Jay Smith, and Yvonne Gaines, 1987

content.description: A direct start for Etude can be done by climbing directly up from the base of the apron below the Flake Out ramp/ledge.

climbs.name: Etude
climbs.fa: Larry Reynolds & R. Wendell, 9/69,  FFA: John Long, Rick Accomazzo, Richard Harrison & Tobin Sorenson, 1974

content.description: This is a fun, clean crack route that requires more finesse than strength.  The delicate crux section, with side pulls and shallow, flared foot jams, is well-protected with fixed pins.  An easier finger and hand crack above leads to the belay.  There is a second pitch, but most people rappel after pitch 1.  This route is located just left of Flower of High Rank.
content.protection: small to medium pieces plus quickdraws for the fixed pins

content.description: Climb the flared finger crack on the right side of the Flakes of Wrath dihedral.  A slightly overhanging start leads to vertical climbing.  This is the direct and harder start to Flakes of Rad.
content.location: Start just to the right of Flakes of Wrath.
